sections.title: Cappadocia
sections.instructions: Read the text about Cappadocia, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
Cappadocia, Turkey, is different from any other place on Earth. It is a very high area: over 1,000 metres above the sea. There are many mountains across this area which are thousands of years old and made from volcanic rock. Some of these mountains are really high. Mt Kayseri, which is the highest, is 3,916 metres!

Because Cappadocia is so high, the weather can change a lot. It can be very hot some days and very cold other days.

The people who lived in Cappadocia many years ago made small houses inside the mountains and rocks. You should visit it because you can explore inside the mountains and see how the people lived!

sections.title: The Project
sections.instructions: Read the story about Katy, Mike and Harold, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
Katy, Mike and Harold were in the library talking about a project about Turkey. Mr Carlton, their teacher, said they could choose any topic for their project, but it should be about Turkey.

'Betty's group is doing their project about the geography of Turkey,' said Katy.

Harold was reading about Turkey on a website. 'The history of Turkey is very interesting. It was part of the Ottoman Empire!'

'Freddy's group's doing their project about that,' said Katy. 'What about science?'

'No,' said Harold. He didn't like science. 'The project's for Friday,' she said. 'Let's hurry up!'

Katy looked at her timetable. 'I'm sure that Turkey has lots of stories and myths. These can teach us a lot about a place. Our project can be about Turkish literature.'

'Great idea! We should find one on the Internet. Mr Carlton likes us to use IT,' said Mike.

'Why don't we do something original, like re-write the story as a poem? I'm good at writing poems,' said Katy. 'Mike's good at art. He can draw the pictures. And you're good at acting, Harold. You can read it to the class!'

'Perfect,' said Mike. So that's what they did!

sections.title: The Great Barrier Reef
sections.instructions: Read the text about the Great Barrier Reef, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
The Great Barrier Reef is in the sea near Australia. It is the largest coral reef in the world. It is so big that you can see it from space! The reef is about 2,300 kilometres long.

The reef is home to many different animals. There are over 1,500 types of fish, 400 types of coral and many sea turtles, dolphins and sharks. The water is warm and very clear, so you can see the colourful fish and coral under the water.

Many people visit the Great Barrier Reef every year. They go snorkelling and diving to see the beautiful animals and plants under the sea. Some people take boat trips to see the reef from above.

But the Great Barrier Reef is in danger. The water is getting warmer because of climate change. When the water is too warm, the coral turns white and dies. Scientists are working hard to protect the reef and keep it healthy for the future.

sections.title: Sports Day
sections.instructions: Read the story about Sports Day at Greenfield School, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
Last Friday was Sports Day at Greenfield School. All the students were very excited. There were many different events: running, jumping, throwing and team races.

Emma was in the 100-metre race. She practised every day after school for two weeks. On Sports Day, she ran as fast as she could and came second! She was very happy because last year she came fifth.

Tom was good at throwing. He threw the ball 25 metres in the javelin event. That was the best throw of the day! His teacher, Mrs Davies, gave him a gold medal.

The best part of the day was the team relay race. Each team had four runners. Emma's team, the Blue Team, was winning, but then Jake dropped the baton. The Red Team won the race in the end.

After all the events, everyone had ice cream and lemonade. The headteacher, Mr Patel, said it was the best Sports Day ever. Everyone agreed!

sections.title: Iceland
sections.instructions: Read the text about Iceland, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
Iceland is a small country in the north of Europe. It is an island in the Atlantic Ocean. About 370,000 people live there. The capital city is Reykjavik.

Iceland is famous for its volcanoes. There are over 30 active volcanoes on the island. Sometimes the volcanoes erupt and hot lava comes out. Iceland also has many geysers. A geyser is a hole in the ground where hot water shoots up into the air. The most famous geyser in Iceland is called Strokkur. It erupts every 6 to 10 minutes!

In winter, the days in Iceland are very short. In December, there are only about 4 hours of daylight. But you can see the Northern Lights ‚Äî beautiful green, purple and pink lights that dance across the sky at night.

In summer, it is the opposite. The sun almost never goes down! In June, it is light for almost 24 hours. People call this the 'midnight sun.'

sections.title: The School Trip
sections.instructions: Read the story about the school trip to the museum, then answer the questions.
sections.passage:
On Wednesday, Class 4B went on a school trip to the Natural History Museum. Their teacher, Miss Wilson, took them on the bus. The journey took about 45 minutes.

When they arrived, a museum guide called Anna showed them around. First, they went to the dinosaur room. There was a huge skeleton of a Tyrannosaurus Rex. It was 12 metres long! Jack said it was the best thing he had ever seen.

Next, they visited the room about oceans. They learned about whales, sharks and jellyfish. There was a model of a blue whale hanging from the ceiling. Lily thought it was amazing.

After lunch, they went to the rock and mineral room. They saw diamonds, gold and many colourful crystals. The guide told them that some rocks are millions of years old.

Before they left, everyone visited the gift shop. Jack bought a small model dinosaur and Lily bought a book about ocean animals. On the bus home, Miss Wilson asked them what they had learned. Everyone had a favourite fact to share!
